awd_titl_txt: Continuation of Full-Scale Three Dimensional Numerical Experiments of High-Intensity Particle and Laser Beam Matter Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Particle accelerators are ubiquitous in society as they are used in particle physics, materials science, structural biology, medicine, and transmutation of nuclear waste. In some cases these accelerators are more than a mile long and cost billions of dollars. If a new cheaper and more compact accelerator technology could be developed, it would transform our ability to use particle accelerators and enable their application to an even wider range of problems of scientific and societal benefit. This research will examine fundamental scientific questions aimed at developing compact particle accelerators based on plasma waves (these are waves moving in fully ionized gases) moving near the speed of light. It will also require generating state-of-the-art software that can be used on the nation's largest computers. The students and post-doctoral researchers trained under this grant will be part of the twenty first century work force in computational science and engineering as well as experts in plasma physics and accelerator physics.

This is an award to perform full-scale three-dimensional numerical experiments of high-intensity particle and laser beam-matter interactions to significantly advance the understanding of basic high-energy density science (HEDS) on ultra intense laser and particle beam plasma interactions. This understanding will aid in the quest to make plasma based accelerator stages for use in high energy physics colliders, next generation light sources, medicine, and homeland security.  This work will continue to blend basic research with three-dimensional simulations, including full-scale particle-in-cell modeling of ongoing and planned experiments. High-fidelity full-scale modeling provides the means to extrapolate parameters into regimes that will not be accessible to experiments for years to come. During the past decade, a hierarchy of state-of-the-art PIC codes and data analysis tools for HEDS studies has been developed that not only include the necessary physics but also scale to more than 1,600,000 cores and can run on current many core hardware including GPUs and Intel Phi's. With this set of tools, the UCLA Simulation of Plasma Group is uniquely positioned to continue to make significant progress towards determining the feasibility of building a compact X-Ray Free Electron Laser (XFEL) in the next decade, and a future linear collider based on wakefield sections driven by lasers or particle beams.

por.por_cntn:
One goal of this project is understand how the most powerful lasers and partilce beams in the world behave as they propogate through gases. The electric fields of these lasers and particle beams are large enough to ionize any gas to form a plasma, so the subject of intense laser and particle beam-matter interactions is synonomous with intense laser and particle beam-plasma interactions. This subject is intellectually challenging as it combines ultra-high fields, ultra-fast phenomena, plasma, beam, nonlinear, and relativistic physics, wave-particle interactions, nonlinear optics, and accelerator science.

 

When intense lasers or particle beams propogate into a plasma they displace the electrons in the plasma creating plasma wave wakefields analogously to how a motor boat creates a wake in water. Charged particles can surf on these wakefields to high energies in distances much shorter than in a conventional particle accelerator. For example the electric field (the field that accelerates the particles) in a plasma wave wakefield is 1000  to 100,000 times larger than in a conventional accelerator. The concept of using intense lasers or particle beams to create wakes for accelerating particles is called plasma based acceleration. Progress is this field relies on the synergy between experiment, theory, and advanced simulations. This project uses simulations and  supports the development of complicated software that run on the worlds largest computers, which can have 1,000,000 precessors computing all at the same time. We have developed new simulation algorithms and enhanced our state-of-the art software that follow the motion of billions to trillions of plasma electons and ions based on the forces produced by their positions and motion. We used this software to carry out simulations that have led to new discoveries in plasma physics that could lead to plasma based accelerator being the key technology for building a future linear collider for high energy physics and/or a compact coherent x-ray source. The simulations provide not just a testbed for theoretical ideas and new concepts, but a method for guiding ongoing and future experiments. They also permit exploration of regimes that will not be accessible to experiments for years to come.  We have found that intense lasers can remain focused in low density plasmas for longer than expected distances and discovered new techniques for producing particle beams with unprecedented combinations of currents,  energies,  and angular divergences. We have developed concepts for how to manipulate these beams on nano meter distance scales. We have supported experiments that have shown that plasma based acceleration can be highly efficient and can generated mono energetic beams of positrons. These outcomes are also helping to form a roadmap  for developing new classes of acceleration and radiation sources that migh impact particle physics, material science, structural biology, medicine, fusion research, homeland security, and transmutation of nuclear waste. This project has also advanced the coupling of highly accurate simulations and experimental data to accelerate science  discovery,  led to the training of post-doctoral researchers and graduate students who are now working at national laboratories, and led to the development of software that is being widely used domestically and internationally.
